tagDescription: to Lord Liverpool. Correspondence relative to the Jurisdiction Bill.
to Lady Selkirk. Referring to William Smith's verdict against Lord Selkirk and his departure for New York or England as a probable witness for the North West Company.
to Lord Hopetown. Requesting him to act as his proxy at election of Scottish Peers.
to A.Colvile. Lady Selkirk's baggage shipped. Papers relating to Athabasca forwarded to Hudson's Bay Company Committee. Red River accounts.
to Selkirk. Informing him that no copy of the Jurisdiction Bill has been received from Canada.
Swiss Settlers for Red River to Colvile. (French.) Expressing their contentment. Signed by eleven persons.
to Selkirk. Testifying as to the character and abilities of Captain Roxburgh.
to Lord Liverpool. Enquires about letters sent on 19 and 25 March. No replies received.
circular to various people offering himself for the vacancy in the House of Representatives of Scotland.
to Selkirk. Petition from Burgher's Congregation requesting land for a church.
to Alex. McDonald. Memorandum on letter sent. Township not surveyed.Benefit from the Mission.Infamous conduct of Provincial Governor and the Courts.
to Lord Napier. Regarding his own election as a Scottish Peer.
to John Foster. Requesting him to be present in the House of Commons when the motion is introduced by Sir James Montgomery on Red River matters.
to William Anderson. Regarding the man for Red River, sends form of contract.

to Lady Selkirk. Reports arrival. Court of Quarter Sessions held.Verdict in North West Company case.Attitude taken by Sir Peregrine Maitland. Gourlay,refusing to leave the premises have been imprisoned and will be tried for sedition.
to Lord Haddington. Requesting him to act as his proxy at election of Scottish Representative Peers.
Bill of Indictment for murder gaianst McMillan,de Reinhard,et al.(Appendix C.)
to Selkirk. Pamphlet received.Will attend to matter when it comes before the House of Commons.
to Georges Geddes. Instructions in case McDonald should be absent on arrival of ships for cattle for Red River.
to Selkirk. Forwards his son's complaint of Captain Matthey's conduct.

Hudson's Bay Company to T.Vincent. Remarks on the unfinished sats of the general accounts. Approve Mr.Christie's management; also James Clouston's efforts. Will endeavour to send out a surgeon to replace Mr.Sims who will return home. References to the Alhany district. Arrival of the Eddystone.
to Selkirk. On the reduction of Quit Rents. Result of election. Matters relating to Prince Edward Island.
Affidavit respecting Williamson of the North West Company.
to James Stewart,Halifax. Enclosing duplicate of former letter and new power of attorney.
to Lady Selkirk. Remarks on the Attorney-General and the Jurisdiction Bill. Colonel Nichol returned from England where he sought compensation for losses in late war.
to C.J.Zehnphenning, Dusseldorf. Regarding German and Swiss settlers for the Red River.Requests him to take charge of the matter.
to Selkirk. Regarding men and women willing to go to Red River as settlers.
to Selkirk. Referring to settlers from Caledonia at Wedderburn. Forwards list of lands sold with name of purchases and price said.
to Selkirk. Cannot interfere?Appeal to Crown must be made through Secretary of State for Colonies.
to C.O.Ermatinger. Memorandun of income necessary for Red River settler. Present for old Nolin.
to John Pritchard. Reports on proposed route. Refers to young women weavers.
to Selkirk. Returns Mr.Halkett's letter and accompanying papers.
to J.Stuart. Court of Oyer and Terminer to be held at Quebec 2 November.
to Joseph Berens.Regarding North West Company dispute. Lord Bathurst strongly objects to the Hudson's Bay Company raising a military force.
to John McDonald. Is shipping cattle on the Prince of Wales for Red River to replenish the stock. Pressed hay, catmel sent to feed them.Settlers leaving by same boat.
to Bathurst. Regarding the matter of the Jurisdiction Bill in Upper Canada. Hopes he will take steps to prevent its adoption on his receipt of a copy.
to W.Montrion. Instructions for drawing up Red River leases.
to Bathurst. Protest against the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Act.
to Gale. Informing him of the surrender and trial of Duncan Cameron,partner of the North West Company.
to R.Dickson. ( Duplicate.) Giving instructions about the Red River lands within the Unites States Territory.
to William Smith.Informing him that Sir James Montgomery will raise the question of the Red River business in the House of Commons.
to Gale. Memorandum on Colony affairs.Bell ordered for the Red River church.Suggests Scots Benedictines,lately deprived of their lands in Bavaria,for Canada.
to J.Allan,Jr. Replying to his application for a situation.
to Selkirk. Everything ready by 7 May. Customs regulations.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo. Letter of the 17th instant received.Measures will be taken for arrest of Mr.Black for violence done to Colin Robertson. Objections to use of military.
to Huerter. Licences obtained for passengers.Account of provisions necessary.
to A.Campbell. Will forward the £20 allowance for Mrs. McLean.
to Colonel Ready. Regarding the trials.
to J.Wedderburn. Refers to money matters. Dispute with the North West Company and unavoidable expenses.
to James Woods. Referring to horses and cattle for the Settlement.
Suggestions for a temporary judicature for Red River Settlement disputes.
to James Stewart. Regarding affairs in Prince Edward Island. Letter to Johnston enclosed.
Charge of Grand Jury delivered by the Chief Justice.Referred to by Simpson.(Appendix B.)
to Alexander Cuddie. Is to have charge of settlers.
to Maitland. Referring to method for apprehension of Mr.Black.Protest made by Company.
to R.Laidlaw. Men and seeds to be at Gravesend on 22 May. Applications received from men willing to go to Canada.
to-----. Regarding the trials at York and damage imposed.
to Selkirk. Remarks on Prince Edward Island lands.McMillan's claim.Proposed memoir on Governor Smith's administration.

to Lady Selkirk. Hears unfavourable report of Captain Matthey,and his marriage. Court proceedings at York.Treatment of Hudson's Bay Company a lesson to the Province.Judge Foucher reinstated; considers it an insult to the House of Assembly.
to Selkirk. Offering assistance in procuring Swiss settlers for Red River. Answered 25 September.
to Lord Liverpool. Referring to acharge against Judge Ogden of Montreal. George Campbell's case; charges against him.
to -----. Regarding the Johnstone estate and canal to be built. Recommends Mr.Greig.
Hudson's Bay Company to William Williams. Importance attached to the Athabasca trade. Hopes Robertson may be induced to continue in command.
to C.Marshall. Considers plan for Court to try North West Company servants impracticable.
Governor of Red River. Proclamation to the loyal servants who defended the lives and properties of the inhabitants. Offers pension to any maimed or hurt.
to W.Anderson. Regarding arrears of rent and condition of farm of Pardovan; reduction asked for.
to Bishop Plessis. Will write to Colvile regarding missionaries. Importance of good understanding between Catholics and Presbyterians in Settlement. Caution as to proselytism.
Messrs.North,Simpson & Graham to Selkirk. Account of goods bought.
to Selkirk. Engaging servants for the Red River Settlement.Interferred with by Sir A.McKenzie and the Sheriff of Ross.List of those engaged.Four young gentlemen sent out as clerks.
to Ready. Regarding the execution of a warrant for arrest of Mr.Black.
Declaration and confession.(French.) Before Lord Selkirk. Justice of the Peace. Witness:J.Matthey,J.W.Dease,John Allan and Alex. Bridport Becher.(Appendix.)
to Bathurst. Further remarks on the subject of Lord Selkirk's arrrest.
to Selkirk. Wishes to re-enter the Hudson's Bay Service.Men engaged and ready to go out as settlers.
to J.Halkett. Letter of January 30 received. Refers to reasons for Lord Selkirk's arrest.
Duke of Richmond to Selkirk. Has received his memorial of 20 October; considers matter one for legal decision.
to Selkirk. Report regarding Captain Roxburgh's qualities.
to Selkirk. Reference to money matters.
to Selkirk. Pamphlet produced and read. Impression made. Measures suggested.
to Selkirk. Applying for engagement in the Hudson's Bay Company. His father and brothers would accompany him.
to Lady Selkirk. On the building of a local church.
to Lord Hopetown. Expressing his thanks for his interest in the election; its effect in Canada. The trials and Lord Bathurst's action.
to Huerter. Memorandum on land grants for Swiss settlers.Instructions for passage money and for letters.
to Selkirk. Offering his services.
to General McComb. Hopes for good understanding between himself and Lord Selkirk's representative at Red River.
to Selkirk. Regarding imports into Canada.
to Selkirk. Pamphlets received.Has forwarded a set of Irish Union bag pipes to Captain Miles McDonell.

to John Greig. Referring to proceedings in Upper Canada. Desires establishment of friendly intercourse between Captain Matthey and United States Commandant at Yellow Stone River.Lord Selkirk unable to return.
to Selkirk. Suggets strong measures be taken against Lord Bathurst.Impressed by the Pamphlet.
List of persons taken at Grand Rapid by Governor Williams.Copy sent to Duke of Richmond.
to Robert Laidlaw. Received his letter with list of people; very satisfactory. Instructions.
to Selkirk. Difficulties in hiring men for Red River. Seed grain advised as best suited listed.
to Selkirk. Requesting instructions regarding the measurement of Captain McMillan's land in Prince Edward Island.
to A.Colvile. Further offer to procure settlers. Ideas for obtaining suitable persons.
to John Greig. Enquires about Red River lands and American Treaty.
to Selkirk. Attitude of Highland proprietors on emigration to Red River. Enquires if a township has been set apart for him at Red River.Encloses his account.
to Lord Liverpool. Transmits documents referred to in his letter to Lord Bathurst of 8 February.
Secretary to ----Scarlett. His case is to be brought up in the House of Commons.
to Selkirk. In connection with the publication of his letter to Lord Liverpool in The Scotsman and other papers.
to Selkirk. Regarding the Duke of Richmond's answer to his memorial.Observations on events in connection with the trials.
to J.Ready. Sees many difficulties in the course proposed for trials.
to Selkirk. Report on estate.
to Selkirk. Upper Canada Jurisdiction Act forwarded to Prince Regent for determination.
to A.Colvile. Encloses the letter from James Glen.
(Lord Lyndhurst.) Opinion as to right of private presecutor to employ counsel in Bill of Indictment.
to Selkirk. Servants for Red River engaged. Suggestion as to horses for the Colony.
to Selkirk. Reports on his voyage. Good character of the Scotch and German settlers. Cattle arrived in good order.
to Selkirk. Observations on the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Act.
Hudson's Bay Company to C.Robertson. Express satisfaction that he is going to Athabasca to trade.
to Selkirk. General report on the Settlement.Suggestions to Mr.Logan in August.
to Selkirk. Had posted letters on arrival.
Hudson's Bay Company to James Bird. Remarks on the trade; hopes for better returns for outlay in all the departments.
to Richard Sharp. Forwarding papers relating to the late Governor Semple.
to Bird. Requesting him to send home books and papers left at Red River.
to Lady Selkirk. Remarks on the difficulties of getting the expedition started. Mentions affairs in the Colony.
to James Wood and D.Washburn. Petition to be presented to the King in Council against the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Bill.

to Matthey. Memorandum on buildings to be erected at Red River. A fortified dwelling,frams buildings, a mill,sawmill and various workshops for carpenters,coopers,blacksmiths,tinsmiths,potters and others.
to Selkirk. On various matters relating to the Settlement. Living conditions could be improved.
to A.Colvile. Particulars of Mrs. McLean's petition and the proclamation made by Miles McDonell promising pensions.
to Selkirk. Bill for printing letter to Lord Liverpool.
to Selkirk. Expressing his desire to take up a grant of 800 acres assigned to him in Canada.Would take out certain artisans.
to Colvile. Is disappointed in not receiving papers.
to J.Allan. Refers to the Memorial to the Duke of Richmond. McLellan's sentence. Payments made by Baldoon settlers.
to Selkirk. Reference to an instrument for distillation.
to Selkirk. Informing him of land sales made in Township of Wedderburn. Difficulties caused by Sheriff's executions. Account of disbursements.
to George Garden. Suggests that Captain d'Orsennens assist in selecting the brigade for Red River.
to A. Colvile. Inquiring as to his son's salary.
to Ldy Selkirk. Informing her the letter to has been printed. Hopes Halkett may replace himself at Red River.
to Gale. (Confidential.) Regarding wintering partners.
to J.Pritchard.(French.) Report on Swiss emigrants. Condition necessary for success in obtaining settlers.
to Lord Glasgow. Thanks him for his vote at the late election.
to Selkirk. Expressing his interest in the debate on the Red River Settlement in the House of Commons.
to Selkirk. Pamphlet received.Confirms opinion already formed.
to Selkirk. Regarding the sale of land in the Township of Wedderburn.Forwards statement and accounts.
to General McComb. Expresses his thanks for his assistance in the Detroit lawsuit.Fears further aggressions during the coming summer.
to Lady Selkirk. Reportof trial .Encloses certificate of acquittal.Captain Hall not dead as reported.Letter received from William Moir. Details of his movements and return journey.
to Selkirk.(Copy.) General report of his activities.
to Selkirk. Regarding the Court of Oyer and Terminer proceedings at York, 22 February. Terms for personal service.
to Samuel Gale. Requesting him to enquire about his Red River lands south of the 49".
to Selkirk. Report of Red River affairs and statement of expenses.

to Lady Selkirk. General report on the Settlement affairs,legal and legislative proceedings.Forwarded Indian deed to Matthey.Ridout robbed of £2000 in bills entrusted to him by the Bank.Petition prepared to Prince Regent against the Jurisdiction Act.
to R.Harmay. In connection with land at Kirkdale.
to James Allan.(Copy). Describing William Coltman's conduct at the Sault,in 1817. Hudson's Bay Canoes detained by Major Fletcher.
to Robert Laidlaw. Advising him to engage the men for Red River, and number of passages available in Hudson's Bay Company ships. Men to be in London 25 May.
to Selkirk. Offers to return to Red River to relieve Mr.Logan at a salary of £250.per annum. Settlers, crops and cattle.
Agreement signed by twenty Red River settlers to contribute towards a Presbyterian minister.
to J.Allan. Informing him of Court proceedings during present term. His intentions in various cases.
to Miles McDonell. Expresses Lord Selkirk's thanks for his services. Not advisable that he return to the Red River. Commission to be returned to Hudson's Bay Directors.
to William Anderson. Is averse to altering the contract with Laidlaw's men.
to Selkirk. Brigade leaving for Red River.Despatches for Governor Williams and others well on their way. Committee authorized Robert Logan to take charge of the Settlement.
to Archibald Campbell. Requested by Selkirk to enquire further into Mrs. McLean's memorial.
Vicar-General Provencher to Lady Selkirk. (French.) General report on the Catholic Mission and activities at Red River.
to Selkirk. Acknowledges letter of 8 February and will transmit it to Lord Bathurst.
to Selkirk. (French.) Remarks on personal affairs and colony matters.
to Selkirk. Applying for assistance for Mrs.McLean who lost her husband at Red River.
to R.Laidlaw. Further remarks regarding his son.
to Lady Selkirk. On estate affairs.
to Seton & Plower.Regarding a draft of deeds to J.Halkett.
to Mr.Moffat. Explaining his conduct in not admitting Mr.Gourlay to bail.
to Bathurst.(Draft letter.) Further remarks on the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Act.
to A.Colvile. Reports arrival of Swiss Settlers for Red River.
to J.Halkett.(Copy.Private.) Allan's petition respecting the Act of the Upper Canada Act should be made to the King in Council.
to Selkirk. Payment for men going to Red River. Bond for Archibald Montgomery. Laidlaw's demand for cash.
to Selkirk. Has undertaken to fill the contract of cattle for Red River.
to Lady Selkirk. Referring to estate matters.
to Lord Liverpool. Rectifies mistake in previous letter of date of Red River Settlement.
to J.McDonald. Encloses letters for Red River. Settlers to sign bonds for passage money.
Red River Settlers to Selkirk. Statement of their misfortunes, disappointments,and difficulties.Describe the loss sustained by the grasshoppers plague.Signed by 18.
to Lady Selkirk. Gives account of Court of Oyer and Terminer at Quebec. Cameron's surrender.
to Robert Dickson. The Upper Canada petition to the King in Council.
Memorial from Mrs.Christian McLean.
to Gale. Informing him of proceedings in the Legislature regarding the Jurisdiction Act.Chief Justice Powell's interference.
to Selkirk. Transmits despatches received from Red River relating to events there.
Warrant issued for arrest of North West Company partners for the Athabasca outrages.
to C.O.Ermatinger. Suggesting his salary be paid in Hudson's Bay Company stock.
to Selkirk. Regarding German settlers for Red River. Inventions for preparing clay and cutting brick.
to Maitland,Garden and Auldjo.(Copy.) Regarding lands of Grand River bought from the Indians by Selkirk.
List of papers entrusted to Mr.Pritchard.
Executors of the late Lord Selkirk pay Mrs. McLean's allowance.
to Selkirk. Date of sailing of Laidlaw's men.
Affidavit respecting the papers and documents relative to the trial of McMillan and Reinhard.
to Selkirk. Extracts from his son's letter describing Red River Settlement.
to Lady Selkirk. Applying for assistance from Lord Selkirk towards the cost of settling ,on account of services performed.
to Colvile. Considers it too late in season to send settlers from Holland to Red River.
to Lord Sidmonth. Forwards copy of J.Halkett's letter of 30 January to Lord Bathurst.
Bishop Plessis to Selkirk.(French.) Explains need of money for Red River Mission. Requests collections be made in England.
to James Stuart. Court of Oyer and Terminer to be appointed in November for trial of offences in the Indian Territory.
to A.Colvile.Disapproves of Laidlaw's sending so many things to his son,especially as his young son is not going to join him.
to Lady Selkirk. Matters relating to the Colony.Asks directions for forwarding letters from Lord Selkirk.
to Selkirk. Report of his efforts to ascertain the name of the author of the "Highlande's" letters published in 1811.
Bishop Plessis to Lady Selkirk.(French.) Query as to Treaty of 20 October,1818, with the United States on lands granted the Red River Mission.
Affidavit respecting the papers and documents relative to the trials at York,U.C.
to de May. Forwards of attorney to enable him to contract for persons going to Red River as settlers. Further instructions.
to Lady Selkirk. Refers to Athabasca news and to Duke of Richmond's reply to the Memorial.
to Lady Selkirk. Giving her a full account of the trials and the results.
to Selkirk. General report of affairs at the Colony. Crops.Horses obtained from the Mandan Indians by Archibald MacDonell. The new farm houses burnt to the ground.
to Colvile. Acknowledging receipt of papers.
to Selkirk. Request for money.
to Selkirk. Encloses two letters published in 1811 under the signature of "A Highlander". Labourers going to Red River.
to R.Dickson. Referring to cost of cattle to Red River.
to Lady Selkirk. Money matters. The building of a new church.
to G.Garden. Regarding legal proceeding at York.
to Selkirk. Will attend to papers relative to trials in Canada.Brief prepared for Counsel.
Calculations regarding the cost of living at Red River Settlement.
to Selkirk. Approves very strongly his letter to Lord Liverpool.

to Selkirk. Letter of 25 September received; will submit it to Lord Harrowby.Mentions a commission sent to inquire into affairs between the North West Company and the Hudson's Bay Company by the Duke of Richmond before his death.
to John Pritchard. Personal matters. Asks for money.
to Selkirk. Forwarding a Parliamentary petition to the Prince Regent on the Jurisdiction Act. Nothing has been done respecting Astor's pretended claim.
to R.Laidlaw. Approves his son coming to Canada. Regrets men's objections to contract. Gives additional list of seeds that would be useful.
to A.Campbell. Further remarks relating to Mrs. McLean's petition.
to J.Stuart. On the matter of the trials.
Regarding the payment of £20 to Mrs. McLean from Lord Selkirk.
to Lord Reddington. Advising him of his election as a Scotch Peer.
to Selkirk. Objections raised by Laidlaw's men to contract. Form of contract enclosed.
to Selkirk. Remarks his request for a situation in the Red River Settlement.

to Selkirk. General report on Settlement affairs. Praises Governor Williams.Remarks on Upper Canada legislative proceedings.Robertson free and at Cumberland House. Shaw,McTavish and McIntosh arrive with proclamation.Explains the habits of the grasshoppers and the destruction caused by them. Shortage of provisions.
to Gale. Regarding the Act passed by Legislature as to commencement of indictment by Crown Lawyers.
to S.Gale. Referring to arrangements with Congress on Red River lands.Possible prosecutions.Proposes petition to King-in-Council on Jurisdiction Law.
to Edward Roberts. Requests £50 promised by Lord Selkirk be sent to prepare him for journey to Red River.
to Colonel Ready. His objection not to Court but to early date named.
to Robert Laidlaw. Obliged for his letter. Authorizez him to engage men for the Settlement. Expenses will be paid.
to J.Wardrope. Inducements offered for a medical man to go to Red River.Offers £100 per anum
--------- to Lord Sidmonth.
to Selkirk. Refers to a bond to St. Andrew's College.Laidlaw collecting men for the Settlement.
to Selkirk. Explaining his reasons for leaving Red River Settlement. Offers to return and assist the new settlers.
to William Williams. (Copy.) Further agression on the part of the North West Company.Applying to him,as Governor-in-Chief of Rupert's Land,for aid to curb these activities in Athabasca.
to Selkirk (Private). On family matters.
______ to Lord Sidmonth. Advising him of charges brought against Selkirk for having taken possession of Fort William. Canadians favourably impressed by Sir J. Sherbrooks.
Maitland,Garden & Co. to Lt.Colonel Ready. Regarding renewed aggressions and acts of violence of North West Company.Seeks protection and redress for Red River Settlement.
to Marquis of Lanadowne. Requesting him to investigate the papers relating to proceedings in Canada.
to Selkirk. Has submitted Charter of the Hudson's Bay Company to the Prince Regent for a decision by the Privy Council.Date for hearing not settled.
to Selkirk.(French.) Regarding missionaries for the Red River.
to Judge Stewart, Halifax. Respecting Prince Edward Island lands. McMillan's application.
to Selkirk. Seeking assistance and advice.
to S.Greig. Acknowledges letter of 24 November. Instructions for Captain Roxburgh.
to John Allan. Upper Canada Crown officers instructed not to oppose postponement of trial on Lord Bathurst's recommendation.
to J.Stuart. Regarding the trials.
to Selkirk. (French.) Engaging settlers for Red River.
to G.Garden. Refers to accounts. Indictment of McGillivray for conspiracy. Libel suit against the Editor of the Herald.
to J.Pritchard. Unable to find a suitable schoolmaster for Red River Settlement.
to Lady Selkirk. Has seen the decision of the Courts. Is taking a strong party of Indians with him. Many people anxious to go to Red River from the American side. Supplies ordered for the Settlement.
to Selkirk. Further remarks about his son's salary.
to W.D.Powell. Replying to his letter of the 10th instant.
to Selkirk. Refers to engaging men for the Red River Settlement. Forwards Laidlaw's memorandum on engaging settlers and terms offered.
to Lady Selkirk. General report of his movements.
to Selkirk. Returns Power of Attorney to Mr.Gale.Will pay attention to his wishes in regard to the Settlers. Copies of his letter to Lord Liverpool.
to Selkirk. Considers Hudson's Bay Company objections to conditions of Red River land grants of little weight. Offers his services.
to Lady Selkirk. Is anxious about the petition against the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Act.
to Selkirk. Requests his recommendation towards his appointment as Receiver General of Upper Canada.
to Selkirk. His youngest son wishes to join his brother in Canada. Asks for a recommendation for himself as a land steward. Is authorized to draw his son's pay.
to Gale. Power of Attorney.(Copy of Form.)
to J.Allan. Acknowledges copies of affidavit and memorial.
Certificate of Lord Selkirk's acquittal at Sandwich, by G.T.F.Ireland,clerk of the Western District.
Enclosure:- Receipt for 29 packages shipped for London on the Lord Wellington,S.B.Weitch,Master.
to Selkirk. Packages and men for Red River have left. Shipping receipt enclosed.
to Selkirk. Regarding his brother's claim to Morror estate.
Commissions of Oyer and Terminer and general Goal Delivery.(Appendix A.) Referred to in W.S.Simpson's affidavit of 31 December.Signed by Sir John Sherbrooke.
to W.Wilberforce. Thanking him for his interest in the Settlement,and in the debate in the House of Commons.
to Selkirk. Reporting total destruction of crops by grasshoppers. Affairs at the Settlement.
to Selkirk. Pamphlets received and delivered.Professors of St.Andrew's College and the loan.Recommendation for Lieut.J.Oxley who seeks employment at Red River. Enclosure:-
to Selkirk. Enclosing annuity bonds for servants; accounts relative to Red River.
6666 to Lord Sidmonth. Scroll letter describing atrocities and destruction of Red River Colony.
to J.Berens. Form of conveyance for lands to retired servants of the Hudson's Bay Company.
to A.Colvile. Had conversation with Goulburn regarding Charter. Compromise recommended.
to Selkirk. Account for goods supplied to Colonel Dickson.
to Lady Selkirk. Report on the Upper Canada Jurisdiction Bill.
List of men and women engaged for the Red River Settlement.
to George Garden. Memorandum of general instructions.
to A.Colvile. Report of journey.Is hopeful of obtaining settlers for Red River.
to R.Laidlaw. Assures him of assistance. Financial arrangements with his son explained. Date of Hudson's Bay ships sailing.
to Selkirk. Enquires terms of engagement for his son. Ploughs and seeds ready for shipment.
to Selkirk. Red River affairs to be brought before the House of Commons. Will assist in every way.
to Selkirk. Further information regarding the Duke of Richmond's attitude.Proposed Court for November abandoned. Correspondence terminated.
to Selkirk. Arrangements for payments for Baldoon. Professor Leslie's idea for defining the limits of North America by a land expedition.
to -----. His account with Lord Selkirk.
___ to G.Garden. Relating to money transactions with Colonel Dickson and Dewsman.Does not approve Lord Selkirk's becoming security for Dickson; Hudson's Bay Company has no connection with him.
to J.S.(Lady Selkirk). Sent letters by the Importer on 10 February for Red River.Action to be taken by Matthey in case of attack.
to J.S. Various matters retaling trials and Red River affairs.
to Messrs. Coutle & Co. Requesting them to enquire at Coblentz for F.D.Huerter.
to G.Garden. (Copy.) No arrangement made to ship cattle to the Red River; Dowsman to enquire as to expense.Forwards list of settlers going to Red River 18 June, in 5 canoes.
to George Garden. Forwards letters to Red River. Refers to the Upper Canada Jurisdiction and warrants. Instructions relative to Settlement affairs.
to Bathurst. (Copy.) Forwards copies of his letters to Lord Liverpool ;observations on the contents.
to Lady Selkirk. Estate affairs. Settlement with Mr.Smith.
to Selkirk. Returns papers sent.No observations made on item.
to Selkirk. Report of estate affairs.
to Selkirk. Estate affairs.
law Agent to Bathurst. Requesting information of the receipt of Upper Canada Attorney General's Jurisdiction Bill; character of the Bill.
to A.Colvile. Referring to Mrs.McLean.
to John Hall. Account of his travels in Spain,and suggestions for Lord and Lady Selkirk.
Arrangement between d'Orsennens and Mr.Dease of North West Company.(Appendix E.)(French.)
to Selkirk. Personal money matters. His will. Deeds and jointure in favor of the Countess.
to Selkirk. Various personal money transactions.
to Lord Sidmonth. Forwards papers relative to the late proceedins in Canada. Mentions his election as a Scotch Bear.
to A.Colvile. Referring to Swiss settlers for Red River.
to Selkirk. Laidlaw's men sailed on the Wellington for Gravesend. Has shown his letter to friends and will circulate it freely to remove impressions enemies are widely propogating.
to J.Ridout. Is willing to receive assistance of Prosecutor's Counsel.
to Selkirk. Red River Colony account, 1819.

Hudson's Bay Company to W.Williams. The Prince of Wales arrival,on 14 Octobre. Regrets the loss of the Britannia. Mentions Colonel Dickson's project: considers Mr.Swain may be profitably employed.Refers to trade in the Athabasca district. Officers in charge of posts held responsible for goods and provisions.Accounts at each posts.Accounts for 1816-17 were burnt in the Britannia.Requests of Kennedy to Sutherland,F.Heron and McFarlane to return to EnglandEnquires for James Bruin killed at Red River in 1816.Donald Sutherland's wages applied for; was killed with Governor Semple.
to John Allan. Effect of Lord Selkirk's Memorial on the Governor-General. Proposed measures to be taken.
to James Wedderburn. Men to be engaged for Red River by Mr. Laidlaw.
to James Wardrop. Extract of letter relating to a pupil,Alexander Cuddie.
to W.Anderson. Introducing Lieut.Oxley.
to Lady Selkirk. (French.) Relating the Red River affairs.
to Bathurst. Correspondence in full regarding the dispute between the Hudson's Bay Company and the North West Company,trials.
to Selkirk.Forwards list of persons against whom Bills were found for murder.Agressions by North West Company. Mentions death of Duke of Richmond.
to Sir P.Murray. Referring to his election to the House of Representatives as a Scotch Peer.
to Selkirk. Has engaged 21 servants for Red River. Hears his agency for the Hudson's Bay Company has been offered to another person.

to Lady Selkirk. North West Company complain of alleged attack by Governor Williams and Captain F.Matthey on their canoes. Death of the Duke of Richmond; the cause and general opinion of his administration. North West Company report of destruction by grasshoppers at Red River. Anxious to know terms for wintering partners.
to G.Garden. Memorandun regarding cattle for the settlement sent via United States territory.
to Bishop Plessis.(French.) Replying to his question regarding land south of the 49". Men for the Red River.
to Selkirk. Personal matters. Had seen Sir John and Lady Sherbrooks.
to Selkirk. Mr.Goulburn's letters received.
to Selkirk. Gives a general report of his movements.Agreement with Michael Dowsman for cattle.
to Selkirk. Applying for a situation in the Hudson's Bay Company service.
to W. Mure. Advising Captain Roxburgh to go quietly to Red River.
to Captain de May. Agreement for transporting settlers to Red River.
to Selkirk. Personal matters relating to his estate and will.
to Selkirk. Regarding price and arrangements for delivering cattle to Red River.
to Selkirk. Asking for money to enable him to join his son Donald at Red River.
to Lord Archibald Hamilton. Regarding the discussion of the Hudson's Bay and North West Company controversy in Parliament.Offers assistance.
to John Greig. Fears designs of North West Company on Red River Settlement. Refers to Robert Dickson's licence to trade.
